awd_titl_txt: The Internet of Things Education Project
awd_abstract_narration:
A convergence of technologies has given rise to cyber-physical systems known as the Internet of Things (IoT). IoT applications incorporate networks of advanced sensors and actuators, embedded intelligence, and networking technologies to provide control that were not previously possible. IoT technology has the potential to affect nearly every aspect of human endeavor and commerce by increasing system efficiency and reducing energy consumption. It also can provide real-time monitoring of the nation's infrastructure and environment and has the potential to improve public health, safety, and national security. This project has four objectives. First, it will create and test interdisciplinary IoT learning material in electronics, computing, and networking. Second, it will broadly disseminate the materials through established networks such as the Advanced Technological Education Centers. Third, the project will develop teacher and faculty expertise in IoT and active-learner technologies. Fourth, it will interest under-represented groups in STEM fields by recruiting K-12 students into summer workshops. It is vitally important that the United States be at the forefront of the development of this technology and has a workforce that can install, maintain, and update this emerging technology. This project has the potential to provide the necessary curricula and training to teachers, who can educate the IoT technicians needed to work in this critical and evolving area. 

This multi-interdisciplinary project aims to improve STEM-related undergraduate education in electronics, computing, and networking technology areas. It also aims to improve education in non-electronics-based technologies that use cyber-physical systems to provide advanced automation and control functions and enhance system efficiency, safety, and security. The project will develop courses, modules, labs, and simulations. These teaching resources will focus on advanced manufacturing or Industrial IoT, IoT cybersecurity, e-healthcare IoT applications, and IoT based advanced automotive technologies. The project will create an IoT Systems Field Technician option or certificate under existing electronics, computing, and networking programs. The certificate has the potential to benefit incumbent workers and is expected to be of greater benefit to students pursuing degrees in areas such as Biomedical Equipment Repair or Mechanical Engineering Technology than a standalone IoT degree. Broad dissemination of the results and an emphasis on cultivating high school teacher and college faculty expertise will support broad impact. The project impact is broadened further by recruitment of diverse K-12 students to participate in summer workshops. These workshops will expose K-12 students to coding, sensors, data acquisition, interactive virtual labs, simulations, and low-cost computing platforms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Internet of Things (IoT) Education Project is a National Science Foundation (NSF) funded Advanced Technological Education (ATE) project awarded to Springfield Technical Community College (STCC). Originally funded for three years (2018 -2021) for $650k, this project ran for five years due to the Covid-19 pandemic (i.e. two additional no-cost extension years were employed). The project’s major goals were to: (1) Develop curricula for a one-year certificate in IoT (courses, modules, laboratories, and simulations), (2) Disseminate the developed materials at regional and national conferences, (3) Develop faculty (two- and four-year college faculty and middle- and high-school STEM teachers) expertise in IoT technology and its applications through hands-on workshops, and (4) Recruit under-represented groups into STEM disciplines.

The project team consists of the PI, Gary Mullett (STCC faculty), and the Co-PIs, Ed Bigos (STCC faculty), Yakov Cherner (ATEL), and Aura Ganz (UMass faculty), and Senior personnel, subject matter experts (SMEs) Andrew Collins (STCC faculty) and Jeff Cooper (STCC faculty). The project evaluator was the Davis Square Research Associates.

During the first year of the grant (summer of 2019), three STEM teacher workshops were held (30 participants with a waiting list) and two IoT workshops (IoT camps) for College for Kids were held. Plans were in progress to repeat these activities during the summer of 2020 and to also hold in person two- and four-year college faculty workshops. Introductory IoT curriculum was developed, and a one-year IoT Certificate was passed through the STCC curriculum committee. This new certificate originally fell under the Electronics Technology AS Degree but that had to be changed to the Computer Systems Engineering Technology AS Degree program when the Electronics program was suspended.

When the Covid-19 pandemic caused major disruptions to educational institutions in March of 2020, all activities for this grant basically ceased. Faculty spent all their time putting courses online. During the summer of 2021, when it appeared that the college would reopen during the next academic year but with a limited on-campus presence the decision was made to change to virtual faculty workshops due to the unknown duration of Covid-19 restrictions. PI Mullett, Co-PI Bigos, and SME expert Collins developed the bulk of the virtual online materials. We recruited college faculty to participate and ran a total of four virtual workshops from 2021 until 2023. An unexpected consequence of running virtual workshops was that we could reach faculty from all over the country not just those in New England. We had a total of 55 participants sign up and 46 completed the workshops. In our original proposal we had a goal of 43 participants. During the summers of 2022 and 2023 we also presented in person hands-on workshops for local middle- and high-school STEM teachers. For the duration of the grant, we had 85 STEM teachers participate when we originally had a proposed goal of 76. Unfortunately, due to Covid-19 disruptions and personnel turnover in the College for Kids program we were unsuccessful in repeating what we had done in 2019 but hope to restart those “camps” in 2024.

The PI has made numerous presentations at national conferences about the project and the developed materials, laboratories, and simulations (i.e. ASEE Conference for Industry and Education Collaboration (CIEC) Conferences, ASEE Annual Conference and Exhibition, the Annual Hi-Tec Conference, and the annual NSF PI Conference held in Washington, DC). During the Covid-19 pandemic, some of these presentations about the project were done virtually.
